Award.AwardTitle: Teaching Sustainability through Problem Based Learning Communities: Professional Development for the Teachers of Tomorrow's Green Economy Technicians

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Community Colleges of Spokane are initiating a professional development program for K-12 and community college faculty where participants develop problem-based learning communities to provide the pipeline to technical careers that have become part of the green economy. Teams of faculty and industry partners will develop real-world, interdisciplinary, industry-based sustainability problems that address recognized skills gaps in the current science and technology workforce. Interdisciplinary teams of teachers will complete online sustainability and systems thinking modules prior to integrating these concepts into problem-based learning communities. A summer workshop introducing problem-based learning and integrative interdisciplinary courses, industry partnerships and site visits, and a web-based support community will provide faculty with the resources to integrate sustainability into science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) technical curricula. Instructional approaches will improve student performance and increase completion rates, particularly for underrepresented minorities, while fostering student interest in regional STEM technical careers. This project will provide a model for training green collar workers in regions that lack a well-defined green jobs subsector, yet are seeing growth in their green economy. Furthermore, the systems thinking approaches used in sustainability can be applied to many other problems in the workforce. Academic conferences and publications, combined with an established online presence via the Pacific Northwest Center for Excellence for Clean Energy (PNCECE), will help to disseminate these findings and to provide resources for training technicians for today's green economy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through funding from a small, first-time NSF ATE grant, Spokane Falls Community College has created a professional development program for K-12 and community college teachers to integrate sustainability into their curricula. Research suggests that the green economy is growing, but it is growing largely through the integration of sustainability into existing technical jobs rather than through the development of separate, new green jobs. Employers are seeking employees that have formal technical training, and have the ability to apply systems thinking, adapt, problem solve, communicate, and work effectively as part of a team in ways that allow their companies to adapt to a rapidly evolving business landscape while considering economic efficiency, social responsibility, and environmental risk.

The primary objectives of this project were to 1) increase K-12 and community college instructors’ knowledge of sustainability and science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) technician opportunities; 2) involve teachers in practical applications of course content and sustainability in the workplace; and 3) facilitate teachers’ implementation of sustainability-integrated problem-based learning communities in their curriculum.

We accomplished these goals by 1) offering summer workshops for teachers; 2) facilitating industry partnerships to help teachers develop more authentic problems; 3) providing support during assignment, unit, module, or course development and implementation; and 4) providing supplemental resources for teachers in print and online.

The project resulted in two summer workshops in which two cohorts of teachers received training and resources in sustainability, systems thinking, problem-based learning, developing interdisciplinary integrative assignments and courses (i.e., learning communities), and industry partnerships. Evaluations and feedback from the first cohort of teachers allowed us to revise and improve professional development resources for a second cohort of teachers. The workshops provided time for teachers to apply the principles learned by developing problem-based assignments to be used in their classrooms. Assignments, units, modules, or courses were further revised and implemented by the first cohort following the workshop. The second cohort will be implementing their assignments in the following academic year.

We have produced a successful professional development model for integrating sustainability, systems thinking, and the soft skills desired by industry into STEM technician pathways. The industry partnerships and resources that were compiled and developed as part of this project provide the foundation to offer future workshops. We have shared our professional development model for integrating sustainability through problem-based learning communities, including successes, challenges, and recommendations at two conferences and intend to further disseminate this work.
